ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I had no idea how little I knew about water issues before taking this course. I learned an immense amount about the history of water and will now be able to take that with me as context for the environmental work I hope to do in the future. I also was able to improve my writing and research skills with Professor Lee's helpful guidance.
History of water

I thought this course was fantastic for furthering my understanding of and interest in environmental history and policy. Professor Lees focus on writing and the writing process definitely improved my writing skills.

I learned how to write a longer history paper and how to use the archive. 

It also exposed me to the history of dams, as well as stories from around the world about how communities respond to water crises.

I learned that water is an incredible lens through which to view the world, particularly the power dynamics of the world and how human societies interact with the "natural" world. I also had the chance to work on my writing a ton. Prof. Lee gave tons of helpful guidance and feedback. We did archival research which was so fun and interesting, and it was an awesome learning experience.

I became a much stronger writer through Professor Lees guidance and feedback. The reading assignments were varied and interesting. I definitely gained a broad yet also nuanced understanding of the history of water issues and how public and scientific opinion has changed over time.
This course helped me learn how to write a historical paper more than anything. I hadnt ever written a lengthy historical research paper prior to taking this class.
I learned so much about the social side of water. It was an extremely interesting and engaging course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The content and back and forth writing assignments with Professor Lee are all excellent. I would say the only drawback was that it was hard for me personally to fully engage with the often fast-paced rhythm of the student led discussion time. As a more reflective type person I struggled to jump in on the topics before new ideas emerged.
Class was very well organized.
Professor Lee was a wealth of knowledge. This class is a very fascinating topic and so many readings are so interesting. It just is much too America centered to really be a global water course.

Strengths- great enviro history course, engaging readings
Weaknesses- I wish prof lee had guided discussion more and provided more background for readings. I felt that I had more background knowledge about water than most students in this course, so was fine, but I and talked with others about how they felt a little lost and lacked context.

Strengths: Film project. Dr. Lee's extensive feedback on papers. Good readings!

Weaknesses: Class length meant that sometimes discussions felt too open-ended.

Strengths: film paper, working on writing, prof. Lee, class discussion

Weaknesses: sometimes, there was more reading than I could handle, but fortunately, I was able to get a ton out of the just by focusing in on what I could each week
The course is strong, and I think we generally used each class very well.

I really liked the course and especially the way the final paper was set up. We had goals all throughout the semester to finish the paper and I think that really helped me improve as a writer and didn't make it feel like a last minute paper.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, absolutely a must-take course if you are interested in water issues.
Absolutely! Professor Lee is amazing and the readings are really interesting.
I think that this course is ideal for a student who is already invested in environmental history and/or environmental/water policy.

Yes! Prof. Lee was fantastic, my writing really improved, and I learned a ton about the relationship between water and people. Which is really the relationship between the natural world and people and power and people.
I would absolutely recommend this course to other history majors, although it helps to have a keen interest in environmental history.
Yes, especially if you're interested in water related fields.

extras.title: HIST 408J 01 - Global Water in the Modern Era
